Javins v. First Nat. Realty Corp., 428 F.raw_text: Javins v. First Nat. Realty Corp., 428 F.2d 1071 (D.C. Cir. 1970)
Javins v. First Nat. Realty Corp., 428 F.proposition: See Restatement (Second) of Property: Landlord and Tenant § 16.1 (1977) (covenant of quiet enjoyment); Javins v. First Nat. Realty Corp., 428 F.2d 1071 (D.C. Cir. 1970) (recognizing tenant remedies for landlord’s breach of lease obligations and interference with habitability and enjoyment); see also Hilder v. St. Peter, 478 A.2d 202 (R.I. 1984) (discussing landlord responsibility for tenants’ habitability and enjoyment); cf. cases and authorities cited below.

Hilder v. St. Peter, 478 A.2d 202 (R.I..proposition: See Restatement (Second) of Property: Landlord and Tenant § 16.1 (1977) (covenant of quiet enjoyment); Javins v. First Nat. Realty Corp., 428 F.2d 1071 (D.C. Cir. 1970) (recognizing tenant remedies for landlord’s breach of lease obligations and interference with habitability and enjoyment); see also Hilder v. St. Peter, 478 A.2d 202 (R.I. 1984) (discussing landlord responsibility for tenants’ habitability and enjoyment); cf. cases and authorities cited below.
Hilder v. St. Peter, 478 A.2d 202 (R.I..support_reasoning: The proposition cites Hilder v. St. Peter for discussing landlord responsibility for tenants’ habitability and enjoyment and in parallel with Javins and the Restatement’s quiet enjoyment framework. The opinion squarely adopts an implied warranty of habitability in residential leases, ties the tenant’s rent obligation to the landlord’s duty to maintain habitable premises, and details remedies (damages, rent withholding, repair-and-deduct, punitive damages) when that duty is breached. This directly concerns and supports the notion of landlord responsibility for tenants’ habitability and enjoyment and tenant remedies upon breach.
Hilder v. St. Peter, 478 A.2d 202 (R.I..relevant_excerpt: Therefore, we now hold expressly that in the rental of any residential dwelling unit an implied warranty exists in the lease, whether oral or written, that the landlord will deliver over and maintain, throughout the period of the tenancy, premises that are safe, clean and fit for human habitation. … Because of our holding in this case, the doctrine of constructive eviction, wherein the tenant must abandon in order to escape liability for rent, is no longer viable. When … the landlord breaches the implied warranty of habitability, the tenant may withhold future rent, and may also seek damages in the amount of rent previously paid.
